articles.author: John R
articles.description:
Day 2, was more productive than anticipated.
https://oneaday.dev/one-hundred-apis
Here is the outline of what has been done:
Vue3.js components updated, adding a way to navigate the APIs as development progresses. I also added a pinia store that drives/binds selection between the dropdown and the v-show. 
I have added a second endpoint, this one is an Interest Repayment Calculation a handy little calculation that can be used to quickly get an idea of how much borrowing money costs over time. I also added in a bottom part to show the JSON response as pretty print.
I did not use Python this time! I have noticed that a request that involves a python script has a slight delay. This isn't a problem for big heavy tasks, but in these early API developments, the small delay is a little annoying. So the Interest Repayment Calculation is PHP only. 
The UI is still a little raw, but in time I will polish it.
articles.title: 100APIsOfCode : Day 2

articles.author: Drew Marshall
articles.description:
I‚Äôm building three companies from the ground up:
üé∏ WINK Guitar ‚Äî hand-crafted guitars, amps, pedals, and educational content

üíª Citrusworx ‚Äî open source software & developer tools (Kiwi Engine, Juice, Nectarine, and more)

üéÆ SubLime Studios ‚Äî a creative game & entertainment studio blending storytelling, art, and design



Each of these companies represents a piece of me. They‚Äôre not side projects‚Äîthey‚Äôre core to my mission: to create a career I don‚Äôt need to escape from. One rooted in creativity, ownership, and long-term impact.
But staying focused across such a wide scope is hard.
That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm starting this series. Daily Debug is my personal changelog. My ship log. My compass.
Each day, I‚Äôll write:
‚úÖ What I got done
üß† What I learned (or struggled with)
üéØ What I plan for tomorrow
üí≠ A quick reflection
This isn‚Äôt for hype. It‚Äôs for momentum.
Because the only way to build something meaningful is to show up daily‚Äîeven if it‚Äôs just one line of code or one decision made.
Let‚Äôs get to it.
articles.title: Daily Debug ‚Äî Day 0: Why I‚Äôm Writing This

articles.author: Odinaka Joy
articles.description:
Deep learning can feel overwhelming at first, but it's just a powerful way computers learn patterns from data, especially in things like images, language, and sound.  In this note, I share what I have learned so far as a beginner exploring this fascinating field.
Deep Learning is a subset of Machine Learning that uses artificial Neural Networks - especially deep (multi-layered) ones - to learn complex patterns in large amounts of data in order to model and solve complex problems. It excels in tasks involving large amounts of data and complex patterns, such as image recognition, natural language processing and autonomous systems (like self-driving cars). These neural networks mimic how the human brain processes information by identifying patterns and making decisions. Deep Learning models a‚Ä¶
articles.title: A Beginner‚Äôs Note on Deep Learning: Lessons from My Journey

articles.author: Sanjay
articles.description:
In this post, I‚Äôll walk you through the steps I took to set up my RKE2 Kubernetes cluster, configure MetalLB as a load balancer, utilize the Nginx Ingress Controller to route traffic to multiple services, such as Grafana and Nginx, and manage persistent storage using Persistent Volumes (PVs) and Persistent Volume Claims (PVCs).
This was done in a test environment with: 
1 Master node
2 Worker nodes
Your Custom domain: sanjaymaharjann.com.np
Services exposed via Ingress resource:
Grafana ‚Üí grafana.sanjaymaharjann.com.np
Harbor (or NGINX test pod) ‚Üí harbor.sanjaymaharjann.com.np or nginx.sanjaymaharjann.com.np
MetalLB: Assign an IP address to the services of type loadbalancer.
Let‚Äôs dive in! 
RKE2 Cluster     [One master, two worker nodes]
kubectl      [Configured to access your cluster]
Dom‚Ä¶
articles.title: How I Set Up My RKE2 Cluster with Loadbalancer, Ingress Controller, Ingress Resource, TLS, and Persistent Storage

articles.author: Drew Marshall
articles.description:
Fighting Focus


by Drew Winkles
What is the one thing in your life that is non-negotiable?
For me, it's creating my own career.
I've worked for other companies and, truth be told, I fared well. Promotions came, responsibilities grew, and I adapted quickly. But there was always something missing. Sometimes it was that my full skill set wasn‚Äôt being used. Other times, there was no room to grow, or worse‚Äîhard salary caps that punished ambition. The reasons are plenty, but the feeling was consistent: I wanted more.
Not more money (although that‚Äôs part of it). More meaning. More control. More ability to build what I saw in my head without having to pitch it to someone whose vision was smaller than mine. That‚Äôs what led me to start Citrusworx, WINK Guitar, and SubLime Studios.
Three completely ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Fighting Focus

articles.author: Andrej Kireje≈≠
articles.description:
Implementing unit tests for React hooks that interact with a back-end can be challenging, especially when the back-end server is built with NextJS. As of Spring 2025, Copilot does not provide assistance for this task, so developers must rely on their own expertise. We hope that the insights shared in this document will save others in similar situations from spending excessive time searching through resources and attempting to integrate various libraries.
A NextJS application where the NextJS server also is the application‚Äôs back-end server.
A React hook to be tested that heavily interacts with the back-end server.
Node test runner used as testing framework.
In our case the server.ts file is customized to accommodate specific back-end logic and provide global data structures shared among Ne‚Ä¶
articles.title: Unit Testing React Hooks with NextJS Back-End: Challenges and Solutions

articles.author: Tsubasa Kanno
articles.description:
Introduction


With the upcoming Snowflake Summit 2025 starting June 2nd, I'm excited to be heading to San Francisco! If you're attending, I'd love to connect. Unlike my usual focus on generative AI and Streamlit, today I'm diving into an exciting data collaboration update from Snowflake.
Snowflake provides a platform that supports every data architecture pattern, including the ability to realize the Data Mesh vision ‚Äì where each organization takes ownership of their data while enabling others to discover and utilize it. However, implementing Data Mesh hasn't been straightforward. Beyond technical hurdles, operational challenges around cross-organizational coordination and access management have made it difficult for many enterprises to achieve this ideal.
That's where Snowflake's new Orga‚Ä¶
articles.title: From Data Silos to Data Paradise - Organization Listing Approval Workflows in Snowflake

articles.author: Roshan Kr. Sharma
articles.description:
It's been 5 years now, But When I first started out as a junior developer, every time I opened my code editor, it felt like everyone around me had a PhD in "VSCode Sorcery." Every fellow developer made me feel like I was trying to build a rocket with a hammer. Fast forward a bit‚Äîand now I‚Äôm the one answering ‚Äúhow did you do that?‚Äù in meetings. Funny how that works.
AI is the hot topic these days‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs a breakthrough or just another tech fad, we‚Äôll save that debate for another time. But one thing‚Äôs certain: using AI and productivity tools wisely can give you a serious edge. While you‚Äôre getting comfortable with AI, there‚Äôs something even more practical you can do right now‚Äîstop ignoring the tools and shortcuts that make your life easier.
I‚Äôve noticed that a lot of junior to mid-level‚Ä¶
